arch:property.oc:show_val: This locus is fill east of L4008 (cobble area), west of L4019 (curved wall), and north of L4018 (collapsed surface). We extended the south locus after all of the above features were removed. We found clumps of mudbrick collapse at the NE area of the trench but its spotty. In the south of the locus there is an area of soft ashy soil riddled with animal burrows, which we mixed this locus with the rest of the locus in about 1m wide area. The ashy area, L4025, extends 3m which split this locus in two parts. I didn"t assign a new locus to the southern part of the locus until the last day of digging, L4026.
dry brittle silt with some hard mud bricky areas, and one large area of soft ashy silt

There was a lot of pottery in the fill, but it looked like topsoil and subtopsoil because it was so dry and brittle. There are areas of mudbrick collapse in the NE corner and an area of ashy soft soil in the SE.

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area B / Trench 4 / Locus 4020 (Locus)
